DOC.HEAD: Department Acknowledges Oversight In Drawing Up Noriega Charges
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department acknowledged today it failed to follow its own guidelines for considering national security problems when it brought drug charges against Panamanian leader Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``It now appears that there was some rush to draw up the Noriega indictment'' and guidelines requiring a review of national security implications ``may not have been completely followed,'' spokesman David Runkel told reporters. He added, however, ``We believe there is a strong case against General Noriega and that case can be successfully brought to trial.'' In making the statement, Runkel backed away from his assertion on Tuesday that concerns about the disclosure of state secrets in the Noriega case ``have been grossly exaggerated.'' He said national security issues in the case are being or will soon be reviewed by prosecutors in the case and their departmental supervisors. Noriega was ousted as Panama's ruler in a U.S. military invasion Dec. 20 but has found shelter at the Vatican's embassy in Panama City. A major goal of the operation was to return him to the United States for trial on the drug charges. Runkel said the Justice Department policy that may have been overlooked requires that when drawing up indictments on matters involving national security, ``those issues be reviewed prior to or during the process of drawing up the indictment.'' He said such a review would include examination by prosecutors of classified documents. ``I had been informed that that was the policy that had, in fact, been followed in this case,'' Runkel said, adding that this no longer appeared to be the case. He declined to elaborate on the nature of the ``rush'' to draw up the indictment, saying, ``I haven't determined the reason'' for it. Runkel said the department's decision to review the national security issues was an outgrowth of a Dec. 14 meeting of prosecutors in the case with representatives of the Drug Enforcement Administration, FBI and CIA. He said the meeting was called to discuss drug-trafficking indictments returned in 1988 against Noriega in Miami and Tampa, Fla., and a decision was made to proceed with the Miami case. The Washington Post today quoted Richard D. Gregorie, who directed the federal grand jury investigation in Miami that led to one of the indictments, as saying he was never allowed to review all the pertinent CIA files on Noriega. Runkel said Gregorie's statements were also a factor in the Justice Department's decision to review the matter. Concerns about disclosure of secrets in the Noriega case have arisen from reports that he worked closely with the CIA and the Pentagon while he served as the head of Panama's military intelligence service and after he became commander-in-chief in 1983.
